ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed greater knowledge of regional resources in Africa, and how their exploitation and commodification has driven/stunted African development. I also gained skills in reading a lot of information (a new book each week) in a short amount of time but pulling out the most essential details/arguments/themes.
I developed a stronger understanding of the impact of prominent commodities (and their ties to colonialism) on Africa.
I gained a deep understanding of how colonialism impacted resource extraction in Africa and led to the exploitation of the continents mineral wealth.

I had never taken an economic history course before, so this taught me a lot about the role that a commodity can play in the history of a region. As a history major within the African concentration, AFST 368 also reinforced some of my previous studies by demonstrating how colonial-era misdeeds continue to have ramifications in the present.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
STRENGTHS: interesting topics, very well-structured, discussions led by students kept things focused and engaging, students could choose when to write their discussion papers, Prof. Harms is really knowledgeable and has been teaching the class for a long time so it has a clear vision, smaller class size made discussions more personal and fruitful, a diverse range of countries/methods of production/imperial powers are discussed for each commodity so as to avoid an overgeneralized narrative.

WEAKNESSES: sometimes the readings were quite long (though very interesting), making it hard to complete them on time on top of other classwork. However, it wasn't too challenging to discuss them when paired with the student presenter's discussion points
The course readings are very interesting and Professor Harms does a great job facilitating conversation! No weaknesses!
I think that the biggest strength of the course is the open discussion format, which allows students to freely react to the course readings and develop a deep understanding of the course material.

A strength of this class was the reading list. While we were often expected to read a large number of pages, the majority of the books assigned were worth the effort. Unfortunately, the discussion of these texts in seminar was often lacking. I wish Professor Harms took a more active role in class conversations, as it often felt that discussion fizzled out after a mere 30-45 minutes.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! It is a great intro into African history around the colonial period and onward. You not only learn about the different commodities (which are oddly fascinating--I even found myself researching rubber for fun), but also the civil conflicts, global politics, and modern state of the countries. On top of that, there are many different countries covered, not just the ones that immediately spring to mind. The class (at least this year) was a very small group, so we all got to know each other and it felt very comfortable expressing our views. Professor Harms is so knowledgeable on the topic from many years of teaching, and his stories from time spent in Africa are fun to hear about. The assignments aren't too difficult and you get to pick the weeks that you write. Overall, a great class for history and non-history majors alike to take. (plus I learned that the Yale Library has the movie Blood Diamond for free? DiCaprio's accent is gold).
Yes! Professors Harms is so knowledgeable about colonialism and African history in general, and you will walk away with a very nuanced understanding of the subject material.

I would only recommend this class to someone who is already quite interested in either African history or economic history, as there is a lot to get out of the readings. Anyone else would likely be bored, as the course does not lend itself to engagement.
